978F8120330D4B2DB221FB546E9669B9.description: (E) understand the impact of various laws and policies such as The Endangered Species Act, right of capture laws, or Clean Water Act on aquatic systems.

8AF78BAA23BD474E91D850CD544D3E96.description: (D) analyze and discuss how human activities such as fishing, transportation, dams, and recreation influence aquatic environments; and

D3951AFF60994C40A361FEC38BB7906E.description: (C) investigate the role of humans in unbalanced systems such as invasive species, fish farming, cultural eutrophication, or red tides;

E01CBAD5772847B9A34D8409AAC7BFC5.description: (B) analyze the cumulative impact of human population growth on an aquatic system;

6B669CA8EBDA4D9887EDF646582E8850.description: (A) predict effects of chemical, organic, physical, and thermal changes from humans on the living and nonliving components of an aquatic ecosystem;

463724E7CD1744B6A30263B6DBBEB9C1.description: (12) Science concepts. The student understands how human activities impact aquatic environments. The student is expected to:

81C9948CDAC64F55BAC848400F5FAC08.description: (B) evaluate the factors affecting aquatic population cycles.

C4EC12D367BB4570AF8A1633E9E59AE2.description: (A) identify how energy flows and matter cycles through both fresh water and salt water aquatic systems, including food webs, chains, and pyramids; and

A56ED95BB21B4C5ABAAD2C78A03582E0.description: (11) Science concepts. The student knows about the interdependence and interactions that occur in aquatic environments. The student is expected to:

3A4616A46D18439A9B4FEC94C475A2B3.description: (C) compare differences in adaptations of aquatic organisms to fresh water and marine environments.

D366EF0E4DEB4803AD4415945F89B20E.description: (B) compare and describe how adaptations allow an organism to exist within an aquatic environment; and

AD3A2E19B7EF4DE6869D623EE306CCE9.description: (A) classify different aquatic organisms using tools such as dichotomous keys;

6120D67732A64956853DD1742BEEE680.description: (10) Science concepts. The student knows environmental adaptations of aquatic organisms. The student is expected to:

8786FA2D77514CF3989A3DBD7B8A1115.description: (C) identify biological, chemical, geological, and physical components of an aquatic life zone as they relate to the organisms in it.

DA8C82BA084D4376B40C234174246DC4.description: (B) identify the major properties and components of different marine and freshwater life zones; and

59741CF301E74D4191D6E1DA5A7CF000.description: (A) differentiate among freshwater, brackish, and saltwater ecosystems;

D5D60373809641E29DC36251352D1A85.description: (9) Science concepts. The student knows the types and components of aquatic ecosystems. The student is expected to:

6BCE566F56CE4782934975B2355866FC.description: (C) describe and explain fluid dynamics in an upwelling and lake turnover.

4D75BFE8C5C04C9494CF341D69F043BB.description: (B) identify interrelationships between ocean currents, climates, and geologic features; and

52426C5C625E48C0BE10306962D5D1CA.description: (A) demonstrate basic principles of fluid dynamics, including hydrostatic pressure, density, salinity, and buoyancy;

56F6DA7804BE4917A5EC9B624CDD2044.description: (8) Science concepts. The student knows that geological phenomena and fluid dynamics affect aquatic systems. The student is expected to:

CEB60BFE47764B2281E28C37048D88F6.description: (C) identify water quantity and quality in a local watershed.

3B0C5BBA67354BDDAEE4B5A9BEBD7B27.description: (B) identify factors that contribute to how water flows through a watershed; and

11F92530FF884B21AEC578E3777B6A0B.description: (A) identify sources and determine the amounts of water in a watershed, including rainfall, groundwater, and surface water;

66DD5B3EE49D4AE4A849CCFBA6B5513C.description: (7) Science concepts. The student knows the origin and use of water in a watershed. The student is expected to:

C6107AE0185249B1A1B9301A1BFB158B.description: (B) examine the interrelationships between aquatic systems and climate and weather, including El Niรฑo and La Niรฑa, currents, and hurricanes.

B1A17922795846A4BAB306F49CA80984.description: (A) identify the role of carbon, nitrogen, water, and nutrient cycles in an aquatic environment, including upwellings and turnovers; and

439E7130A7EE4CDE903EBED605DE70DE.description: (6) Science concepts. The student knows the role of cycles in an aquatic environment. The student is expected to:

5D21D1DE31084E0187FE028023F403F8.description: (D) identify the interdependence of organisms in an aquatic environment such as in a pond, river, lake, ocean, or aquifer and the biosphere.

E6F994766C7B426A9393A82D54389BB5.description: (C) analyze interrelationships among producers, consumers, and decomposers in a local aquatic ecosystem; and

96E386E747DA488B9B7AA6023D1E605E.description: (B) collect baseline quantitative data, including pH, salinity, temperature, mineral content, nitrogen compounds, and turbidity from an aquatic environment;

6E39D558F2004F7DBC0E73D04EEEFFD0.description: (A) evaluate data over a period of time from an established aquatic environment documenting seasonal changes and the behavior of organisms;

58CC665F79AA425A8CD7F457A1095D6E.description: (5) Science concepts. The student conducts long-term studies on local aquatic environments. Local natural environments are to be preferred over artificial or virtual environments. The student is expected to:

D7D79BF6A4CB4C19A772655809125187.description: (C) collect and evaluate global environmental data using technology such as maps, visualizations, satellite data, Global Positioning System (GPS), Geographic Information System (GIS), weather balloons, buoys, etc.

0775D3E70C2B4338875AB9AFD2E56EE1.description: (B) apply systems thinking to the examination of aquatic environments, including positive and negative feedback cycles; and

701198F749864E5E8C4CAF99406F74ED.description: (A) identify key features and characteristics of atmospheric, geological, hydrological, and biological systems as they relate to aquatic environments;

DC140DE55CAD436CA21215BEE53FCA3B.description: (4) Science concepts. Students know that aquatic environments are the product of Earth systems interactions. The student is expected to:

F8A9B4BC0BB54F3C98AE8291BA1BBB44.description: (F) research and describe the history of aquatic science and contributions of scientists.

DDEEA4343AE34B71B32441FBF8E9D4A5.description: (E) describe the connection between aquatic science and future careers; and

893A829CED52478EA1BDD043B4E0D586.description: (D) evaluate the impact of research and technology on scientific thought, society, and the environment;

E0D7AD418D24445E8A07E44465F5C971.description: (C) draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services;

C40E6808763B4335B163F34E981BA335.description: (B) communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials;

D9FC1026B83C4B5EAA80659193A4462B.description: (A) in all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

FC3C24F13C7E4BE394A2F79DA051A61C.description: (3) Scientific processes. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions within and outside the classroom. The student is expected to:

185A0E4B8AA54B2EBB7CD5E2EF1B4F40.description: (J) communicate valid conclusions using essential vocabulary and multiple modes of expression such as lab reports, labeled drawings, graphic organizers, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports.

C6D362F587D24DB29BE4E4AB07362737.description: (I) perform calculations using dimensional analysis, significant digits, and scientific notation; and

ACE02AC987DE4288A67BBD2B628B1163.description: (H) organize, analyze, evaluate, build models, make inferences, and predict trends from data;

165CAA0DF4DF418F970B21D73D715FFD.description: (G) demonstrate the use of course apparatuses, equipment, techniques, and procedures;

66BF6F36FF65461490F47E7D26FC145D.description: (F) collect data individually or collaboratively, make measurements with precision and accuracy, record values using appropriate units, and calculate statistically relevant quantities to describe data, including mean, median, and range;

C3A1813E41014AEEA053F7DCC5AE3252.description: (E) plan and implement investigative procedures, including asking questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and selecting, handling, and maintaining appropriate equipment and technology;

4802473D66244C71930833880FC4E2AA.description: (D) distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories;

2A37964857FD43ED89A1C10734DEE78E.description: (C) know that scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well-established and highly-reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed;

EDB0A3F8877A42A29D91694020644F13.description: (B) know that scientific hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power which have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories;

E682C09837E24971A96745AFDB26DB18.description: (A) know the definition of science and understand that it has limitations, as specified in subsection (b)(2) of this section;

F369F1F0E9F94CBABD639BA514034268.description: (2) Scientific processes. The student uses scientific methods during laboratory and field investigations. The student is expected to:

4B440DAC8FC54BB19A4A55C6F7283A89.description: (B) demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

C9EC3736389C4D3EB4938AAD919345F2.description: (A) demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations, including chemical, electrical, and fire safety, and safe handling of live and preserved organisms; and

0C52F01BE6254669AA4760795D2D18D1.description: (1) Scientific processes. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices. The student is expected to:
